description.text:
It was fun to have used the blockscad left the latter a silicone mold so that they only print only once and manufacture hundreds of silicone and also if they like to print the male even though I think it will be more expensive. but anyway whatever the result. Thank you, it was nice to work with blockscad This design is not to offend anyone, there are geometries that may offend , but as the design says that cultures meet between Judaism, Buddhism, Hinduism, Mulsumana, Christianity. with this I can express that any geometry repeated several times by itself can be infinite. Snowflakes generally adopt a geometric shape based on the hexagon, although depending on the conditions of humidity and temperature, they can form snowflakes whose geometry is based on the triangle or dodecagon. and in itself is a Christmas symbol with meaning of love, peace and harmony, happiness.

Judaism: Star of David
Christianity: Cross in a circle
Buddhism: swastika
mulsumana: the moon
Hinduism: the flower of life.

thingiverse.com, if you think the design is inappropriate, please let me know or just delete it, greetings and thanks

title: Anet A8 And Clones Compact Dual Extuder Carriage with Front Mount 18mm, 12mm, or 8mm Sensor!

description.text:
This is my compact version of my other Anet A8 dual extruder heads. This uses two E3D extruders and has bed leveling sensor mounted as close as I could possibly get it.

Here's the build timelapse!
https://youtu.be/tFMRo3YnjW0

This is the front mount sensor version! Everything FITS!

You can see in the last 4 photos that the head does not heat up much. It's been prionted in heat change PLA that shifts brown to green at about 35c. Hour into this print and it's barely changed since the cold air from the fans passes through the print.

I made this one to put the sensor as close as possible to the heads. I think this is the tightest it could possibly be.

It has built in cooling ducts for the extruders and mounts for the stock 30mm fans built in. I used Mistral 2.1A 4.5 from www.thingiverse.com/thing:2121279 as my cooling ducts. You need to mirror one for the other side but they fit and work great. In theory this should fit any Anet A9 fan duct.

The back is just the no sensor one from my other mount: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2734717

The fan spacers are included to help clearance the fans. Different ducts fit different ways but with the one listed above I found 2 spacers on ear screw worked great. For the lower screw on the side fans be sure to put it through the mount first then spacers and fan with the nut on the fan so it clears the 30mm cooling fans in the front. See pictures!

To print choose your parts:

  • 18mm Sensor With Chain
  • 12mm Sensor With Chain

  • 8mm Sensor With Chain

    To do:
    -Make versions without chain

To use this please read below!

Get the latest Skynet3D firmware from https://github.com/thijsk/Skynet3d and please update your firmware as follows:

Enable RAMPS boards, this is for the common ones like https://goo.gl/XW91zh [Amazon.com link] PLEASE pay attention and be sure to choose the correct code for your motherboards. See boards.h in the Skynet firmware for a list.

define MOTHERBOARD BOARD_RAMPS_14_EEB

Enable dual extruders:

define EXTRUDERS 2

Offsets for the extruders:

define HOTEND_OFFSET_X {0.0, 35.00}
define HOTEND_OFFSET_Y {0.0, 0.00}

For the probe it's :

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 17 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -23 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -0.5 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle Set this to your machine. I used a .5mm thick print put between the bed and probe with the nozzle touching the bed to start.]

And the travel limits are:

// Travel limits after homing (units are in mm)

define X_MAX_POS 240
define X_MIN_POS -10
define Y_MAX_POS 230
define Y_MIN_POS -13
define Z_MAX_POS 230
define Z_MIN_POS 0

You also must set

// Set the boundaries for probing (where the probe can reach).

define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20
define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 200
define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 190
define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 20

I have made a guide in PDF form available here https://goo.gl/1s8jSR for setting the offsets. You will need a serial connection to your printer and I found using Octoprint is really easy.

Here's a crapCAD schematic of the optocoupler board I made to run the 12v probe completely isolated from the RAMPS board.

Enjoy! Like! Leave a comment! Thank you!

title: Anet A8 Easy Auto Off with Included Plugin

description.text:
Update Video of the models and plugin in action: https://youtu.be/fnMHeWjzpq8

Plugin designed and tested with CURA. 2.7+ - Included Plugin for Easy Use

Update I'm overwhelmed at the amount of views and downloads in the first few hours of this 'thing'. This is my first ever created/submitted 'thing' and I'd love to make more. Please leave a comment if this is working out for you and any suggestions you may have. I'd like to take the feedback into consideration for future creation of things. I appreciate it! <3

Note, I'm trying to see if there is GCode that will move the extruder further than 220mm (the build plate width) to the right. If anyone knows, please share. Currently if the extruder reaches the far right edge (model dependent) of the buildplate with the "Auto Off" plugin enabled, it will shut off the printer.

I was unhappy with the other "Auto Off' parts for Anet A8. This is my first Printer. Aswell, I didn't want to modify GCode each time to make the extruder move to the "Off Position". I hacked together a plugin to do this and created the parts from scratch. I'm sure I've done things inefficiently - Feel free to comment on better ways to modify my plugin or model.

Place the AutoOff.py file in ?:\Cura ?\plugins\PostProcessingPlugin\scripts\ folder

When slicing your target files that you want to turn off after printing; In Cura select: Extensions->Post Processing->Modify G-Code and select "Auto Off"

Your print will run the 'Stock' End code, and then without moving vertically will move to the far right to engage power off button.
Anet A8 Power Off, Auto Off, Shut Down, Shutdown

author: TyFactor

title: Geoffs SMD Dual USB Soldering Iron Holder - Mk3

description.text:
I've recently started using SMD components, as cheap, professional quality PCS's are now readily available. I personally use easyEDA, with it's free on-line Schematic & PCB design tools & low cost PCB manufacture.

I found soldering easy my normal iron & a tiny tip, but De-Soldering is quite difficult for small resistors & caps, as both sides need to be heated at once, and the hot-air rework tool just gets nearby components too hot IMHO.

I searched Thingiverse & found minipimmer's "3D-printed SMD soldering tweezers" https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1934731 but found the soldering irons kept falling out.

SO - here is my version, that has worked OK on unsoldering a few SMD resistors & caps, plus it's very easy to remove an iron for single soldering iron jobs - I like using these instead of my temperature controlled Hakko, as these $7 USB irons heat up many times faster (no very useful for big soldering jobs, of course)

I have included my scad source code, so you can modify it for different printers or irons

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1UJna823ziW

Markus Kruse of Terrain4Print just released some awesome Ulvheim buildings and ruins. He indicated that he didn't plan on building a roof in the near future, and I wanted to flesh my buildings/ruins out with some roof trusses. I created this set of hand-hewn, wood-peg, timber medieval trusses in various states of disrepair to complement his buildings.

The set includes a complete, undamaged truss, two variations of complete but damaged trusses, and 2 partial damaged trusses than can be placed on the ground, leaning against the inside walls, etc. The damaged parts can be painted up to look like they had weapon damage from siege engines, fire, rot, acid, etc.

I also created some matching scatter beams/timbers you can find here

Printing Notes: The max angle is about 55 degrees, and there's a small portion in the center of the complete trusses that need to bridge an 11mm gap - which most printers with a cooling fan should be able to do. I recommend printing with a raft or brim to get good adhesion so the parts stay rooted upright during print (I used a 12mm raft with success).

You can support Markus on Patreon if you like his work. Also check out EC3D on Facebook! where I give away premium model sets to a follower twice a month!, and check out my premium sets for sale on Hero's Hoard

description.text:
After half a year i finally found time to learn OpenSCAD and recreate the Flying Combat Platform: Now fully parametric, so you can customize the model to fit your needs.

I also included a new middle platform.

Parameters you can change include the size of the squares, the number of squares in a platform and the tolerances (and other aspects) of the connecting pieces.

The .stl provided is my standard layout with a 4x4 base, a 3x3 middle and a 2x2 top platform.

The design is a work in progress, i'd appreciate your feedback!

Edits:

  • v0.6 – added variables for the number of rows in a platform to support irregular bases (e.g. 1x2 squares)
  • v0.5 – fixed small errors regarding correct use of tolerances for pins and holes of the connectors
  • v0.4 – fixed a small error in the .scad for connecting pieces larger than the squares
  • v0.3 – now with connecting pieces, that i totally failed to include before.

Prusa

i3 MK2S

OpenSCAD

While the initial model was created in blender, this file was recreated from scratch in OpenSCAD so it can be customized and future iterations can be created more easily.

description.text:
Laptops are great computers because they can be carried around easily. But their reduced size and weight mean they have to compromise on certain practical usability aspects. One issue is the low height of the screen, which can lead to neck pain.
Onigiri is a modular laptop stand that raises your laptop display to a much more comfortable and healthy viewing height. The set consists of four stands with different structural patterns that can be printed and assembled in as many colours as desired.

In Japan, Onigiri is a small triangular-shaped snack. It's kind of delicious and that's what inspired the name for the laptop stand.

Designed by Bertrand Clerc

Students are in a rush and often times don’t have time to properly pack up and store all their accessories. The USB Buddy allows them an obvious place to store stylus, pens or ear buds. The USB buddy secures conveniently to a USB port and provides a fun accessible storage for accessories.

description.text:
This is my first 3D Model for an Oven Knob, to replace the factory knob on an Amana self-cleaning oven. The manufacturer claimed they do not produce replacement knobs for the model oven we own. Because of this, I utilized Autodesk Fusion 360 to create a new knob from scratch. Using steel calipers (Digital,) this is the fruit of my first efforts. I printed it on my CR-10 Mini (Using PLA for a prototype,) with 100% infill & a 0.15 Layer Height (Please be advised that I did have to manually rotate the dial; to print it flat from the bottom- up.) I only had to print it once... it is a perfect fit!

Note: in addition to this being the first functional model I have ever designed, it is also the first thing I am uploading to Thingiverse... so please don't be too harsh with the comments.

Printer:

Creality CR-10 Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I have printed this item in PLA; using a raft, to prevent any mistakes that may occur in the print if it were made directly on the bed.

NOTE: I did have to manually rotate the dial; to print it flat from the bottom- up.

Post Processing Requirement (Optional)

After printing, it is intended (Though entirely optional) that the person making the knob fill the hollowed out rectangle (Temperature indicator) on the dial's face with enamel or other colored; self-hardening substance (That won't corrode the print); of a separate color from the printed material.

How this Obven Knob v1 was designed

I designed this model on my Macbook Pro, using Autodesk Fusion 360. Citing a physical version of the semi-melted factory issued knob, I made multiple measurements using stainless steel calipers (Non-digital) which I utilized in making the design's base shape. Since I haven't been using Fusion 360 for very long, I decided to forgo the traditional arch shape of the knob's handle, and instead created the curved back arrow shape with a flat top. This created an advantage of giving the design more gripping space. I hollowed out a rectangle at the point were the knob indicator should go; to aid in setting the temperature correctly.

View of model in Autodesk Fusion 360

Check out the video of how to assemble it here.

This is a set of design to modify a racing handbrake into a handbrake for racing simulators. The KEY FEATURE of this design is using force-sensing rather than a Hall effect sensor or a linear potentiometer to estimate the pulling force. It uses a spring to provide recoil power, gets the axis data from a full bridge thin beam force sensor which is connected to the spring.

Here are several things you need to get it online:

  • Handbrake. I get it from Taobao. You can use "universal hydraulic handbrake" as keywords to search it on eBay. One example is this. This link is just for reference. I don't get it from there.

  • Sensor rack. I use a 12.5mm long 60×15×4mm U-shape aluminum channel to make this part. You may need to file the handbrake a little bit since its width is around 52±0.5mm, while the width of the aluminum slot is 52mm.

  • Spring. I'm using 6×12×55mm, yellow (Light duty) for now. I also tried 60mm long one. For a 6×12×60mm one, the maximum deflection is 30mm, while the maximum force is 137.3N. It works fine. An example with 60mm long can be found here. You can get other sizes if you want to change the force or maximum deflection. But you will also need to change the 3D design base on the type you get. The maximum force applied to the grip of the lever is about 2Kg (hmm, design failure).

  • Rod. Φ5×60mm stainless steel round rod with M3 thread in one end.

  • Arduino. Get an Arduino Pro Micro. Check out the source code here.

  • Force sensor with its' ADC. I get one HX711 weighing sensor module with 20KG scale load cell kit. An example can be found here. You need to modify it a little bit to get a higher report rate (80Hz). Check out the photo of the PCB.

You can get the BOM from the attachments.

Enjoy it!

description.text: Just a little scoop for small amounts of powder to measure for weighing or eyeballing an amount. Sturdy unless you use it as a pry bar, and it has a comfortable handle unlike most powder scoops. If you'l like to measure more powder, just upscale the model. Post-printing, I like to sand around the bowl area and some of the handle that has a flat bottom to make it more comfortable to hold. This really cleans it up and makes it nice. I didn't see any scoops like I wanted on the site, most were too large or didn't have a lip to prevent the powder from falling out on its own. description.text:
Braces for the Creality CR-10 S4 and for the back of the printer since I wanted to place it there rather in the front of the printer. Some inspiration from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2731263 by junaling, Thanks!. This was also an upgrade in order to sync the dual z-axis lead screws, that was done using 2 new lead screws 600mm long TR8x4 (better resolution for the z-axis) (yes I will cut them some day..) and 2 anti backlash nuts that comes with the screws https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Arrival-T8-100-200-300-400-600mm-8mm-Lead-Screw-with-Nut-Kit/32842589445.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.wRxK9y.
I reused the flanged upper ball bearings and the original lid for the bearings. And I used two 30 tooth GT-2 timing pulley bore 8mm https://www.aliexpress.com/item/1PCS-Alumium-GT2-30-teeth-Timing-Pulley-Bore-5mm-8mm-6-35mm-for-width-6mm-belt/32795513753.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.wRxK9y. Then I could use a 976mm long GT2 closed loop timing belt https://www.aliexpress.com/item/1pcs-lot-GT2-900-930-976-closed-loop-rubber-2GT-timing-belt-2GT-900-930-976/32843219839.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.wRxK9y and it fits perfectly between the lead screws. OBS! this is for the S4 printer, I dont know the distance or timing pulleys required for the S3 or S5!
I then used two carbon fiber pipes (10mm OD, 8mm ID) about 534mm long (since it depends on how square your frame is) and glued the link arm with epoxi resin.
Support was only used for the link arm.
Hope that it will attract someone and please show if you also used this setup!

Printer:

My own designed CoreXY

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

35%

Notes:

I printed in PETG but PLA will surely work since it is not exposed to heat or ABS
Some sanding is maybe required for the link arm to fit between the flanges of the top and bottom braces...

description.text: Cute winter decoration for flowerpots or outdoor garden decoration. I used PETG fillament and snowflakes looks like new after 2 winters outdoors.

Print snowflakes

Set more perimeters in slicer. I used 6 perimeters. Snowflakes is more durable and look nicer than lower number of periemeters and infill applied.

Assembling wire

Snowflakes are designed to assemble with dia 2.5mm wire. I used steel zinc plated and PVC coated wire. In Czech republic it is available in hardware stores as wire for mesh fences. Wire has PVC coating which you need to strip down in lengh of the hole in the snowflake and push the wire to the snowflake.

  • If the wire is difficult to push into the hole, it is better to drill a hole with a drill bit dia 2.5 mm

title: Rock Solid Cr-10 E3d V6 5015 Fang with 40mm fan

description.text:
UPDATE 2 :

EZABL and BLToch finally completed and tested are available here for purchasing:
EZABL: https://www.cgtrader.com/3d-print-models/hobby-diy/other/rock-solid-fang-with-ezabl-sensor-mount-3d-print-model
BLTOUCH: https://www.cgtrader.com/3d-print-models/hobby-diy/other/superstrong-fang-with-bltouch-sensor-mount

Regular version is free and available for everybody to download and print
(SOLVED Problem with fang mesh)

Update 1
Released versions with mount for EZABL and Bltouch for beta-testing

I could not find a fang mod for the cr-10 and E3D V6 that i liked because all hang from the 40mm fan, so i made this version which is rock solid and doesn't hang from the fan, but it attaches directly to the incredible "CR-10 Heavy Duty Modular E3D V6 Mount" and it is really sturdy.

The fang i Modded, and the 40mm fan duct are from " v6 Hotend Fan Shroud and 5015 + 40 Fang Combo".

The fang can be printed like a regular fang, with or without supports as you prefer, but i printed with no supports and came out perfect.

The X carriage Mount needs to be printed as it is oriented, and it DOES need supports!

The best materials would be ABS or petg, but i guess pla could hold just fine.

For the Hardware you will need:
To mount the x carriage Mount to the x carriage: 2x M3 6mm
To lock the e3d in place: 2x M3 30mm + 2 M3 Nuts
To attach the fang: 2x M3 10mm
To connect the 5015fan to the fang: 1x M3 25mm or a Ziptie
To attach the 40mm fan to the duct: 4x M3 20mm ( you could use only 2)

For more informations about the "heavy duty modular mount" here is the link to the page with detailed instructions: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2494642

Hope you will like it and that this will satisfy your crave for a decent fang for your creality and e3d v6 ( clone or not :P )

Good prints!

P.S. Tips are always appreciated :) http://paypal.me/neverstopseeking

"Following the release of their lightweight SN-5 frame (with later models dubbed the SN-5L), the esoteric pureveyor of extraordinary combat frames that was the Shinonome Frame Corporation enjoyed decent financial success. Its R&D team went on hiatus not long after, for reasons unknown until now. It seems their leave of absence was not in vain, though. Months after the SN-5's debut, the company prepares to reveal its next fearmongering showstopper, the gargantuan SN-6H. Appropriately named, the Taifu towers above the company's previous instruments of destruction. One would think that this endeavour could spell the end of the company, but near the end of the development hiatus, Shinonome acquired the support of numerous investors from various factions.

The SN-6H Taifu possesses a large stature, a pair of daggers, separate flight systems for both atmospheric and space environments, and a rocket launcher contained within the chest area in a manner resembling the failed SN-3. Unlike the SN-3, the cockpit has been relocated to the abdominal section to prevent casualties from rocket misfires. The "H" in the frame's designation doesn't just refer to its status as a heavy attack platform; it's also a nod to its predecessor, the SN-1H, which featured a similar armament and heft. While the atmospheric flight system consists of four fuel-hungry jets, the spaceflight system uses four pods that split open to reveal arrays of ion thrusters, supplied with a steady stream of power from supercapacitors distributed throughout the body. As such, airbrakes can be found on the forearms, incorporated as a means of reducing fuel consumption while braking; the fuel reserves are rumoured to last no more than 36 hours of use at full power."

title: Double flanged Anet A8 toothed Idler

description.text:
I couldn't find any flanged idlers, that fit the bearings which come with the Anet A8 kit, so I made these. It's designed for 6mm belts and have overall 8mm (resp. 7.6mm) width.

I tested them with a standard GT2 (my X axis) and the belt which comes with the kit (my Y axis).

This is a temporary solution, as the pulleys do tend to break after some time of using. So I recomend ordering metal pulleys (search for 'gt2 idler pulley 20 teeth 3mm bore').

Nozzle temperature and part cooling are key for printing this. Check the individual layers and make sure, the slicer generates the path for the teeth correctly (i.e. they extend all the way out, like in the screenshot). If the teeth still turn out too small or too smooth, try turning down temperature and slow down the print.

I've used a 0.3mm nozzle, but 0.4 might work too.
The parts in the photos are printed with 0.2mm layer height, but 0.1, 0.15 should yield better results

title: Raspberry Pi Zero W Camera case.

description.text:
This is my mod of the case modded by tnw513.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1617437

I've added mounting tabs and a cover for the camera flex cable.
In my printing, I bumped the Deltaprintr so there was a offset in the layers that stuck the 2 halves together :( You can see that in the damaged edges and the closeup last photo.
Still, with a bit of brute force, they were separated.

Also, the RasPiZeroW camera connector clip is broken so tape is used to hold it together.

The RasPiZeroW is loaded with motionEye code by Calin Crisan and just works.
https://github.com/ccrisan/motioneye/wiki
To set the WiFi without a keyboard and monitor...

title: Fate Grand Order Lancer Arturia Lance

description.text:
Warning! Work in progress!!

The lance from Fate Grand Order's Lancer Arturia/Artoria/Altria (ew).
I think I have exhausted the options in Fusion 360 to create a "complicated" pattern on a cone base shape. It is designed to be printed with a transparent material like natural PLA and illuminated from the inside with an LED strip.

The lance itself (100 cm tall!) is split into five parts that fit my printer (maximum height of 240mm), but the full sized lance is available as well. The lance parts simply slide into eachother and should be glued with an epoxy adhesive for maximum strength. The inside can be reinforced with the three inner rings. These rings are specifically designed for one of the lance parts. The rings have an inner diameter of 24mm (perfect size for a broom handle) and have a channel running through them to allow for an LED strip to be integrated into the prop, which is the idea behind this lance.

Future updates will include a proper handle design.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 or even higher

Infill:

Honeycomb (aesthetic), 10-15%

Notes:

Print this prop in transparent material! If you light it from the inside, it will look gorgeous.

Requirements

What you need:
Sandpaper up to 500 grit (or higher for a finer finish)
Triangular file
Primer filler spray (Motip)

Smoothen the surface

Use the sandpaper to smoothen the flat, diamond-shaped surfaces of the lance. Use the triangular file to smoothen the grooves of the lance, as there are some design glitches that I might not be able to fix in the future.

Use filler primer

Further smoothen the surface by using the filler primer and sanding it down. After achieving a smooth finish, use the file to remove all primer spray from the grooves; if you are going to use an LED strip to illuminate the prop from the inside, you want the opaque primer to be completely gone from the grooves. This gives the lance it's illuminated look as light will seep from the woven pattern.

description.text:
V2 uploaded, added ridges on the power and volume buttons for more finger feels. Increased the size of the power button for increased clicky click and increased the camera cutout corner radii for maximum smoothness.

//

I've always wanted a slim case which also shows the back dBrand sticker for my Galaxy S7 but could never find one. This case started out as a challenge for me to design a tight fitting case but grew to something much more frustrating, this is the result after many revisions.

The case is extremely thin, an average of just 0.66mm thickness from a model I've made of my S7. There is a small lip around the screen which allows the phone to lie screen down without the home button or screen touching the surface below.

I suggest printing this with a nozzle of 0.3mm with a line thickness of 0.33mm or with a 0.2mm nozzle with a 0.22mm line thickness and using supports up to about 2mm.

There are two versions, one has a headphone jack hole which should be able to fit most small/medium sized plugs and the other does not have the hole. I suggest printing the on without if you're only using bluetooth headphones because the hole is quite big and could potentially compromise the rigidity.

After printing you'll propably have to seperate the volume and power buttons from the case a little to make them click better.

After printing the original design I noticed my 10k LIN potentiometer didn't fit the design. I used a Piher PC16SH-10IP06-103A2020 potentiometer.
Therefore I made this remix of only the bottom part. All other parts remain the same as the original design.

I cut the potentiometer shaft to 11mm. The ribs on the shaft hold the small gear in place.

Assembly is easy:

  1. Mount the potentiometer in place (do not tighten nut yet)
  2. Connect top and bottom part by using the gear/shaft part
  3. Drill holes to fix the shaft to the top part
  4. Mount the middle double gear
  5. Move the top part all the way forward (toe position)
  6. Turn the potentiometer fully counterclockwise
  7. Slide the small gear over the shaft so it meets the larger gear without moving any other parts.
  8. When everything is in place and working, tighten potentiometer nut

I use this as an Expression pedal for the Keith McMillen Softstep 2 MIDI foot controller. I therefore used potentiometer value and connection used in Roland's EV-5. After calibrating this pedal in Softstep Advanced Editor I get a MIDI value range of 8 (heel position) --> 127 (toe position).

Connections I made to make it work as the Roland EV-5:
1/4" stereo jack --> 10k LIN potentiometer
tip (+5V) --> white wire
ring (output) --> red wire
sleeve (ground) --> shield

Prusa p3 uses direct extruder so the x-carriage is very heavy as it holds the x-axis motor. Bowden extruder seperates the motor from the hotend thus the x-carriage is lighter, minimizing the swinging during fast returns. This allows better printing. The j-head mount fits to the existing x-carriage screw holes.
I got the extruder parts from aliexpress as low as $ 7. You will also need a J-head hotend (preferably with a cooler fan) and a teflon (PTFE) tube. When you have installed the bowden and the hotend mount, before attaching the tube to the hotend, extrude the filament 5 cm and measure the actual lenght getting out of the tube ("E" in milimeters). Checkout the steps needed for 1 mm extrusion in your firmware which is about 700.
700x50=35000 steps. Then divide 35000 to "E". For example if you measure "E"=120 then 35000/120=291.667 Just change 700 to 291.667 in your firmware.

Also see my spool-holder holding the bowden extruder motor.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2766928

This is a 28mm (1/56th scale) model of a Canadian WW2 Anti Aircraft tank, the "Skink". The Skink was built on the chassis of a Canadian built Grizzly tank; which is essentially an M4A1. The turret holds four x 20mm Polsten auto cannons.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skink_anti-aircraft_tank

I based it on the M4A1 from manifold destiny's https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1037138; upscaling it.

I crafted the turret using Tinkercad.

I have included two turret options; one with the cannon barrels and a second without the barrels, as dependent on your choice of settings and filament, thin barrels can be fragile. I use 1mm aluminium tubing or even sometimes just segments of the jumbo paperclips to simulate barrels. In the barrel-less option, I have left recesses in the gun mounts to aid securing the added barrels.

comments.text:
It would need agreement from your opponent but using the recognized the vehicle design system, written by Richard Humble, who is a Bolt Action guru from the UK. The 9+ armour would cost 110 points, each light auto cannon costs 30 points, and the hull gun costs 10 points. So a regular Skink should be 240 points. There may be an extra 5 point cost for having a turret (or maybe fixed weapons like a Stug cost 5 points less, I can’t find the reference right now). But ball park 240 points.
If you can’t locate the vehicle design system, let me know and I will email you a .pdf copy.
It is a limited production run weapon, but then the Germans only made 18 Sturmtigers and just about every german player seems to have one! The Skink was actually built and had the Luftwaffe not been swept from the skies in 1944 it very well could have been more prominent.
Thanks for your interest.
Marc

author: ElHado

description.text:
What is it?

It is a letter holder for envelopes + content, which allows to place letters vertically to save space and should have enough space for a letter amount of around 1 year of a private person.

Core ideas behind it?

Main goal was to overcome the yearly letter flood as efficient as possible:

  • Possibility to store a full letter after reading/or not reading (envelope+paper) and make use of folders with time-consuming unpacking and sorting of the letters completely obsolete.

  • Different chambers for different topics to cover all the regular needs: bills, banks, official things, ...

  • Enough space for 1 year of permanent storage. In total estimated letters per year were around 40.

  • As compact as possible to store in a drawer, therefore vertical letter storage

  • Like always: Only 3D printed material, lightweight, avoid support structures and in the end therefore cheap

Why this and not others?

That's the tricky part. Found none with the compact vertical approach, one wall-mounted (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:604020) and dozens of 1-chamber designs, which did not suit the permanent, sorted, 1-year storage idea (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:660493). So in the end, the available solutions were pretty far away from my needs.

What is the outcome?

In the end I made my own model, which was already reworked and I think now is "market ready":

  • Printing time of around 5h in average quality and speed.

  • Material usage: ~55g

  • Quite tall structure which may have warping if not sticking properly to printing bed. Printing with raft is recommended.

  • Bridges on top, longest one has ~15mm. Although not really long bridge and should not be a problem, make sure your printer is capable to print this, otherwise use support structure.

  • Very functional (not the prettiest) design, but is stored in the drawer anyway, so does not need to be pretty :P

print_settings.Notes:: Use a brim or ears on the mounting bracket so it doesn't warp off the print bed.  If it warps, you can use a heat gun to carefully straighten it.

title: Cabinet Safety Latch
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Keep toddlers out of kitchen and bathroom cabinets without drilling holes. The latches are designed for double cabinet doors and frame 16 mm thick with at least a 3 mm gap between the doors. An imbedded ballpoint pen spring gives positive lock action.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Choose the vertical or horizontal mount latch depending on the mounting surface. The vertical mount is more secure because pulling on the cabinet doors pulls the bracket tighter against the mounting surface. If the cabinets are below drawers, the mounting surface may be horizontal, so in that case choose the horizontal latch. Both latches use the same mounting bracket.

Be sure to print two knobs. Print all parts in the original orientations for best results. No support required!

Use a brim or ears on the mounting bracket so it doesn't warp off the print bed. If it warps, you can use a heat gun to carefully straighten it.

Assembly

Scrape the mating surfaces of the knobs with a hobby knife so they are super smooth. This will make the glue joint strong and eliminate any gap. Super-glue the knobs onto the latch and press firmly until the glue sets. Scrape the joints to the desired smoothness.

Insert a 4.5 mm diameter (BIC) ballpoint pen spring into the slot in the mounting bracket. Push the latch into place so that it compresses the spring. Align the holes, insert a retaining pin and secure with a retaining clip.

Try the action of the latch. If it is rough, disassemble and sand the inner surfaces of the mounting bracket.

Installation

Apply a strip of double-sided foam tape to the mounting bracket. The knobs should just clear the top of the cabinet in the up position. With the horizontal mount the knobs may stick out from the cabinet in the down and locked position because the axis of rotation is lower than with the vertical mount. Check the fit and action before sticking it in place.

description.text:
I wanted a strain relief bracket which didn't interfere with the bed levelling screws - instead, one that clamped the bed carriage would be ideal using m3 hardware

The one I made is v1. This is version 2, featuring an angle to avoid screws contacting the bed, nut retainer insets and slightly narrowed. I reduced the diameter of the cable channel to get a tighter cinch with the cable ties.

To complete, use two m3 10mm or 12mm bolts and nuts to clamp the carriage, and two small cable ties, just push them through.

Printer:

Creality Ender 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.32mm

Infill:

20

Notes:

To print, rotate onto its side, it shouldn't need supports though a brim may help. If using PLA, print it slightly hotter than normal (PLA+ settings) to increase interlayer bonding. Printed 215-220 deg C to increase strength.

Infill doesn't really matter, 3 perimeters / 1.2mm wall is what I used, it's more than enough.

Designed in Onshape from scratch, if you want to edit it the link is here:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/2d61c918ed37344b6f5f4652/w/5cc150713efcf0918f92af5e/e/7c914fb3f0feff55238d9b94

For when you have a cartridge / pen insert of 3.20mm, but not anymore the "body" (or if you only buy the first).

Beside the voronoi idea, there is also the "laying flat" one that use the principle of showing the infill pattern (no top, no bottom, retract also during the infill, and choose a nice pattern, like "honeycomb").

Just need to design a cap now :)

The provided file may not suit all the existing ink cartridges (3.2mm diam. here), so here is the simple way I did this :

1) extrude an hexagone shape, 9mm diameter, for 100mm
2) with a hole in the center, 5mm diameter
3) use voronator.com to make it nice, I used the parameters "STL + less holes + thicker"
4) remove 0.3-0.5mm from the base to have a flat surface to add a brim to

By using "thicker" before, we have larger cross section surfaces (which is good to extrude at least something), but a smaller diameter : after being "voronoized" the base diameter of 5.00mm is roughly 3.80mm. That was ok for my 3.20mm cartridge.

In order to find the right diameter to draw I had to print and test several diameters, the 4th iteration was the good one.

title: Mastercrafted Wolven Silver Sword - The Witcher

description.text:
Every budding Witcher needs their trusty twin swords, and here we have the Mastercrafted Wolven Silver sword from the Witcher 3. (Steel available at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2761042)

Being scaled to the lore and the game files, the hilt is just over 12" long, and the blade a further 38". A pair of holes are present down the blade in order to house two 2.5 x 1m long carbon fibre cores and keep everything together. These are designed to poke slightly out of the blade and into the hilt for truer centering. A second hole also runs down the length of the hilt and into the blade in order to contain a 1/8" x 3/8" steel core.

The grip is designed so that you can wrap a 3mm thick leather cord around them and have a true look to the game designs.

The runes read "One made of silver" / "for creatures" as a callback to an in-game quote, as well as "Valentine Costumes" (my cosplay brand) - if you wish I am willing to customise this file with your own text or different runes (price dependant on changes) - please feel free to contact me if you're interested in this service.

Due to common transportation issues with large blades such as this, it is designed to come apart where the blade and hilt meet. If you attach the hilt to the aforementioned metal core, you can then drill a 5mm hole in the core at the point where a hole features in the top of the blade (Blade_2 file), and then use a 5mm binding screw to hold it all together.

Please feel free to use / modify this model as you wish, but credit is always appreciated.

Now get out there and kill some monsters

Notes:

Supports only necessary on the pommel, but possibly advised on the grips also

title: Rol game dice trays for battles

description.text:
It's an attempt to create my own board game.

Found it!
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:233029

I start this board game project for people experienced in this type of games.
Thanks to who put this object so that I can modify and create this, and to all those who download it.

There are different trays:

  • Simple, for simple swords, for when the game is started and there is nothing more than a simple sword.
  • Medium, for when you already have a good half sword.
  • Large, when you have a sword that's worth it.

There are also other trays for swords with effects.

  • The simple sword can have a turn-around effect and/or a passive secondary effect.
  • Medium sword can have one effect.

  • I have respected the sizes, so the large one has no effect.

  • Shields protect and can also have effects, but only protection.

I'm refining some, since they have not come out well. Sorry and thanks again.

description.text:
A quirky little skull based on the day of the dead festival aesthetic from Mexico.
This model is flat and designed as a stencil or a coaster but it could also be stuck to a wall for a spooky halloween decoration.

Can be used as a coaster if just printed flat (designed to be the right size for mugs and glasses).
Can also be used for a halloween decoration or for the base of a 3D pen project.

Print in a bigger scale to produce placemats!

The last picture shows the shadow on the glass bed.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I print onto a glass bed so you get a gloss finish on one surface. Use slow first layer speed so it sticks even with the high detail. I like to use a few perimeters so you get the contours around the holes to give you a cool effect.

If using this as a coaster for hot drinks you may want to use a more temperature resistant material then PLA, such as ABS or nylon so it doesn't warp. (Although I have had no problems so far.)

3D Pen Project

1) Print the object (if you want to create the illusion use black or a dark colour).

2) Add colour and detail to the print with a 3D pen to produce a more festival inspired look. You can also add depth to the print with this method. Add colour in the gaps and build up the eyes to create an eye-popping effect! (You need to build up the eyes a fair bit to create the illusion). You could stop here for a cool decoration in itself.

3) Print the object again in white or another lighter colour.

4) Join the two parts together to create the illusion (with a 3D pen) a bigger separation will make the illusion more obvious.

Print at a bigger scale to really exaggerate the detail and make pushing plastic into the gaps easier.

Object after completing step 2 Final 3D object The slight illusion by following all the steps

The contact plate will need trimming both in length and a cutout for the bottle window. description.text:
These are 3-D printed hoof covers for digitigrade stilts my wife made for her Satyr Renaissance Fair costume. The stilts are simple wooden digitigrade stilts that were pretty easy to make (you can find several tutorials online). The 3-D printed covers look great, and more importantly, are lightweight and durable. As these are covers only, all the weight of the wearer is on the stilts themselves.

These covers are made for ~85 mm wide (1x4 lumber) stilts; you may need to adjust them for your own project. After printing, smooth it out and paint, then attach with wood glue and/or screws.

I included the Blender source file, along with two variants of the hoof in STL format. The two variants are left and right leg versions, and have some subtle changes between them.

title: Dual Fang Duct Tevo Tarantula and SN04 Prox Sensor Mount V2

description.text:
This is version 2. I found out after making V1 that the prox sensor set a little too far forward to be effective, so I moved the prox mount back closer to the main bar. I also added a little support for the vertical.

After getting my Tevo Tarantula and hearing everyone rave about the Dual Fang cooling duct, I decided I needed one. But at the same time, I was needing to move my SN04 prox sensor out of that horrendous spot on the back of the extruder so I could adjust it. I found 2 items I needed, but according to the Pauli exclusion, 2 objects cannot occupy the same space at the same time.

So, working with Bryceletarmo, I was able to get the original CAD file for the fan duct. I then used migeorge's design and redrew it in AutoCAD to fit what I needed. Merged the 2 items together, and here we go.

If it wasn't for Bryceletarmo and migeorge's work ahead of me, I am not sure I would have been able to pull this off. Thank you to the both of them.

The fan is a 40x40mm fan, as described by Bryceletarmo. The SN04 mount uses the same bolts and washers provided (at least they worked on mine). I suggest adding a washer on the back side of the printed mount, just to make sure the bolt head or nut doesn't pull through. Fan bolts use the same size as the electronics housing fan (in fact, same size fan). Just thread the bolts through the plastic. Usual warning, don't over tighten or you may strip the plastic out.

title: Game Organizer for Fallout (2017 Board Game) by Fantasy Flight Games

description.text:
These are printable trays designed to keep all the game pieces and cards for your Fallout board game well-organized.

These trays will replace the cardboard insert which comes inside your game box.

I recommend printing these on a printer with a large build area (these were tested on a Taz 5). The part is split into four quadrants.

The top-left quadrant will hold your starting mission cards and whatever else you want to keep on top of them - I use real bottle caps as currency in this game, so I store those there.

The top-right quadrant will hold your hexagonal board tiles. There is also a cylindrical storage area, which I recommend using for your SPECIAL tokens. In the center of the top-left and right quadrants is a spherical storage area, which I recommend using for your quest markers, VATS dice, affliction/karma tokens, and player markers.

The bottom-left quadrant will hold all of your encounter/quest cards, split into two decks. This will allow you to store additional cards if you're the kind of person who writes in your own encounters.

The bottom-right quadrant will hold your starting encounter cards, as well as all asset, loot, player, companion, perk, and shop cards. There is ample room to store additional objects on top of the starting encounter cards (I keep the player miniatures there).

All four quadrants combine to form a compartment in the center that will hold the four character boards used by each player.

Enemy tokens can be stacked and stored horizontally on top of any of the encounter card sections, and will squeeze in quite nicely with enough tension that they do not scatter.

PLEASE NOTE: This was specially designed to fit the Fallout board game, released by Fantasy Flight Games in late 2017.

https://smile.amazon.com/Fantasy-Flight-Games-Fallout-Board/dp/B075B1WNDG/ref=sr_1_2?s=toys-and-games&ie=UTF8&qid=1516729109&sr=1-2&keywords=fallout+board+game

I was challenged to create a passable decorative pokeball for cosplay purposes. These components can be used to construct your own decorative Pokeballs. This kit includes simple primitive models to construct a decorative pokeball. By themselves the included models do not constitute a pokeball, some assembly required. Included Models:
Reinforced Half Sphere
Split Flange
Button Legal Disclaimer: The Pokemon brand is the property of Nintendo. I claim no ownership over their products or trademarks. This is merely a reproduction for decorative purposes only. Do not try to eat the components or final item. Not for children. NOT A TOY! Edit:Replaced misspelled file name. Edit2: Uploaded files with more generalized file names.

1.Print off two half spheres. One white, one red.
2.Print off two split flanges in black.
3.Print off one button in white. Allow the glue to dry for each of the following steps. 4.Glue the half spheres to the split flanges.
5.Glue the opposite ends together ensuring the split flange slots line up.
6.Apply glue to the button tab then insert the tab into the slot.
7.Sand any imperfections.

description.text:
Tevo Tarantula is a nice entry level DIY 3D printer, but there are a few points that should be addressed. The good part that these can be corrected printing some parts. The worst, in my opinion, are the bearing spacers for pulleys. In this printer, pulleys are attached to M5 or M3 screws, but curiously all spacers are the same size, and don´t fit to the inner bearing part. So, I´ve created these simple spacers to replace the standard ones. These were inspired in Pulley Spacers from Noumcreation, but I´ve tried to make it simpler.

It should be printed with 0.3 mm layers from the beggining to the end. It´s a small print, so I recommend to use a slow speed, and any infill should be fine. I´ve used 30%.

Tevo Tarantula

Used PLA and it was fine. Once that layers are going to be pressed, you can print the way it´s in the file. Just don´t overtight. I´ve added a thin washer mounting the M3 supports. I recommend using brim, once area is too small.

All it´s are 6 M5 spacers and 2 M3. I´ve left a spare M3 to the file.

Notes:

Fine resolution for a smoother surface to paint. 15% infill on my test models resulted in playing pieces that were too light. 50% gave them more heft. Hatchbox PLA printed at 200 with the bed at 50.

Rendered the gcode in Cura 3.0. Printing managed by OctoPi.

Prep and painting.

Scraped off any bumps and print debris. Light sanding and prepped with acrylic Gesso. Then painted with Valejo mini paint, though likely any acrylic craft paint would do.

Inspiration

Based on a polyclay design I saw on BoardGame Geek: https://boardgamegeek.com/image/3285590/onitama

A nice clean design to build in Tinkercad.

author: Apel_16

description.text:
Print fan duct with supports, but be sure your slicer doesn't put any inside the fan duct itself, as they will be a nightmare to remove.

Preparation:
You need to remove the original blower fan, and replace it with a more powerful one, like the one in the pictures. Be sure it's 24v

Installation:

  1. Remove the original fan duct from your printer, and screw the adapter on the metal in its place, using the same screw your removed
  2. Remove the original metal fan holder, and install the printed one using the same screws you removed
  3. Snap the fan duct on the adapter, and re-tighten the adapter's screw
  4. Be sure the duct does not hit any other components when X axis is at 0, and you're ready to go.

description.text: I've printed out several of CBiker's great brake disk truing tools but realized that it was too big to print on the awesome little Monoprice Mini printer, so I brought it into SketchUp and resized it so that it'll fit onto the 120mm square build plate of the mini. I also don't use the hole for the magnet but I do like the through hole for hanging it on pegboard, so I ditched the magnet hole and moved the through hole closer to the end. Still has plenty of leverage and is sized exactly the same as the original at the ends.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.175mm

Infill:

50% lines

Notes:

Printed with 4 shells and 50% infill - you shouldn't be bending a rotor so aggressively that you need to print it solid. Even 50% infill is probably overkill.

No rafts - I had to turn off the skirt as it wouldn't fit on the build plate otherwise. Printed well with only a little bit of elephant foot on the smaller slot that I cleaned up with a small file, and it's good to go. Printed in PLA for the same reason as the low infill - this doesn't need to be super strong as it shouldn't be subject to really high forces.

I recently created some hand-hew, wood-peg medieval trusses for Terrain4Print's "Ulvheim Building", and wanted to create some additional pieces of timber and beams for scatter.

This set includes 4 beam/timber variations, and each beam comes in "regular" (undamaged) and a damaged version. The damaged parts can be painted up to look like they had weapon damage from siege engines, fire, rot, acid, etc.

These have detailed sculpting that should hold up well to scaling up as well, and are perfect for use in any damaged building or ruins scenario. They had wood grain sculpted into the bottom but I cut most of it off to make a nice flat bottom for bed adhesion, so one side will be missing detail but that should be OK if you position on your board accordingly.

These should all print without support just fine. You can check out the Trusses (ruined and regular) HERE.

If you like my work, check out EC3D on Facebook, where I give away premium model sets to a follower twice a month!, or check out my premium sets for sale on Hero's Hoard

Calibration print for inserting a home depot 1/4-2 hex bolt. I will probably use this to make a thumbscrew. Since every printer (and filament) is potentially different, I'm going to use this to determine the offset size I need to get the right insertion. Once I get that, I can create a thumbscrew.

Since tinkercad isn't so hot at precise hexagon sizing, I used this calculator
https://rechneronline.de/pi/hexagon.php
d2 is the width (flat to flat distance)
d is the length (point to point distance)
If you want one, you can calculate the other for a precise proportion. Mouse dragging sucks for this.

title: Airsoft Shotgun to M4 magazine adapter

description.text:
This allows you to use standard M4 magazines on airsoft shotguns that use the shell type cartridge. It was made for the Franchi 3 barrel shotgun, but will fit other makes as well.
You will need a small bolt and pen spring for the magazine clip.
This is version V, and is much reinforced over the older versions, and uploaded as separate files.

To assemble, the shell needs to be glued and screwed through the holes provided, I use a drill bit to keep the shell and main housing aligned while I'm putting the screw in.

The rail goes on the right side, and is completely optional

Prints well on my Anet A8 (Prusa i3) using PLA, standard settings.

author: Dwarren

description.text:
I just realized that I meant to post these as a remix from: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:174009

These wheels for the LaTrax Rally are an upgrade over stock wheels which are surprisingly narrow, making the car difficult to drive / keep pointed in the intended direction on more slippery surfaces (basketball courts, polished concrete, etc.).

They are designed to fit on the stock car and to fit Team Associated RC18R tires. I realize these tires are harder to come by, but can usually be found on ebay for about $20 (or your lhs in their archives).

Depending on the body of your car you may have to heat it up slightly with a hair dryer to clear the rear wheels. You will also need to move the body posts to their tallest setting.

I have included a flat face and an concave version of the wheel. The concave is a tougher print. I usually put the flat face wheel face down on the print bed and manually add supports for the hole in the center. I do not support the wheel lip although you will get a strand or two of filament that falls off, which is okay.

description.text: Math signs on cube

I designed this to hold a round sharpening stone from Norton. I have two of them, the IB64 and the JB64. I designed this box so that the top and bottom are exactly the same. All you need to do is print two of the same part.

I do plan to use these magnets and this E6000 Craft Adhesive to hold the box closed when not in use. That's what the 4 indentations are for.

I ordered these 3mm brass rods to use as the hinge pins.

I'm still waiting on the hinge pins, but I printed it and tested it. The hinge is a fairly tight friction fit, but that helps keep it open. Overall, I'm pretty happy with the outcome.

I will use a 3mm drill to make a cleaner more consistent hole in the hinge plastic before I insert the brass rod, but I don't anticipate any issues with that.

Parts: (in case the amazon links don't work)
1) BYKES Neodymium Super Strong Extremely Powerful Rare Earth Refrigerator Magnets 1/2" X 1/16" N42 - Set of 80

2) uxcell 3mm Dia 250mm Length Brass Round Rod Shaft for RC Toy Car

3) E6000 237032 Craft Adhesive, 2 fl oz Clear

4) HATCHBOX PLA 3D Printer Filament, Dimensional Accuracy +/- 0.03 mm, 1 kg Spool, 1.75 mm, Blue

Printer:

Bibo 2 Touch

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I didn't use any supports for the overhanging hinge, but it printed fine. I did use a 10mm brim around the whole box because it's a large flat surface and I didn't want the edges to lift and warp the box. This worked fine and since the box is a square, it was very easy to remove them without ever knowing they were there.

Bed Temp: 60C
Hatchbox PLA Temp: 195C
Measurement and Units Cube
cup

Here's a few small brackets just to maybe help stiffen up the frame a little bit more. Maybe not completely necessary but I guess maybe every little but helps. The purpose of the "anchor" part is to secure the printer to the board my S5 is on top of, so if by any chance the actual entire printer was ever-so-slightly budging at all during prints, it won't now. I don't absolutely know if it was but just in case. These are testing parts.

Revised: "Right" parts added and files renamed. "Right" parts are larger and attach to frame with a bigger footprint. Not possible on left side due to the pulley bracket mount.

PLEASE NOTE: I had a mixup with dimensions and file names. Corrections have been made. The current files are correct. My apologies.

2/4/18 Update: Slightly modified hole locations on Left and Right Z Angles brackets.

description.text: Made with PrintShop ShapeMaker

This Thing is a chassis for a lightsaber prop, holding the electronics inside the hilt. It is designed to hold a DIYino Stardust V2 board supplied by a single Li-Ion Battery of type 18650. It has a separate speaker holder large enough to house a 28mm VECO speaker (from TCSS), which can be attached to the main chassis using the plug (guide pins) on it. The main chassis body has a cutout to hold a micro USB breakout board for charging and programming the Arduino compatible Stardust board as well as an 5mm LED holder for the charge status indication LED (light up if charge is completed).

The chassis has 31mm outer diameter (OD) and therefore fits snugly into any MHS compatible saber hilt from TCSS or any UltraSabers hilt.

title: Livolo touch switch hiding frame with spring - Cadre enjoliveur pour interrupteurs tactiles LIVOLO
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
EN :
Livolo Touch switches are beautiful and very well built. The glass panel is 80x80mm – that is a standard size in Europe – but the part that is pressed to the wall is only 74x74mm. So if you changed your switches and had a loose existing cut of wallpaper or paint around the switches, you might see the edge of the cut…

This hiding frame is intended to cover the cut edge around your switches and gives a nice finish touch while remaining discreet. Springs at the corners are designed to position the frame tight on the wall in case of a loose wall mount. If you cannot easily clip the panel onto the wall mount, just remove the 4 springs at the corners with your nails, it will fit perfectly. The slot on the bottom will allow you to remove the glass panel with a screwdriver as designed by LIVOLO.

Other touch switch brands have likely the same dimensions.

Printed in batches of 9 pieces at 0.2mm layers with white PLA on my 300x300 CR-10 bed.

FR :
Les interrupteurs tactiles Livolo Touch sont très jolis et bien construits. La plaque en verre fait 80x80mm – dimension standard en Europe. Mais ce qui touche le mur fait 74x74mm. Donc si vous aviez découpé le papier ou la peinture un peu trop juste autour des interrupteurs précédents, ça peut se voir…

Cet enjoliveur sert à cacher la misère et donner une belle touche de finition tout en restant discret. Les ressorts dans les coins servent à bien le plaquer au mur en fonction de l’épaisseur. Si vous n’arrivez pas à clipser le panneau de verre, il se peut que vous deviez arracher les ressorts, ça se fait simplement avec l’ongle et le cadre se placera parfaitement au mur. La fente permet de pouvoir facilement démonter la vitre de l’interrupteur avec un tournevis plat comme l’a conçu LIVOLO.

D’autres marques d’interrupteurs tactiles ont probablement les mêmes dimensions.

Imprimé avec du PLA blanc 9 pièces à la fois sur ma CR-10 au plateau de 300x300.

Printer:

Creality CR10

0.2mm

Walls are very thin on purpose.

My original packs are really old. Instead of buying new hand drill or new packs I gave 3D printing a try.

I had a 4S A123 Cells pack handy with standard XT60 plug - so I soldered myself a wire lead that converted XT60 to tabs + extra XT60 for charging using my charger. But the box is big enough to accept 3S 4000mAh packs as well. This will give plenty of space. If necessary you can just cut/slice the pack for your needs. Or scale.

You need to buy yourself car connectors 6.3 mm wide - long.

The way you connect your batter inside is up to you.

Everything is connected with M3x10 c-sunk bolts - 8 pcs (4 insert, 4 back),
1 x M3 x 20 for XT60 holder
4 M3 nuts to attach insert
2 car wire connector

The pack sits firmly in the socket so there was no need to install the locking bracket. So my printed version is not equipped with it.

The back cover is actually 2 piece merged to hide the sliding clamp opening. If you want to have the working clamp that holds the pack against springs then in Slic3er click the button split. And then delete the cover opening. I've printed the clamp but after first assembly I found it not needed. Also my A123 4S pack was too big to fit the clamp inside :( But with smaller cells (3 or 4S lion) I think it will fit nicely.

description.text:
A simply remix of the gantry parts from Greg191134's comprehensive Core XY upgrade for the Creality Ender 4 (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2686559), to reduce twisting inherent to H-bot printers. I've added holes and clearance to continue using pulleys in the H-Bot configuration, which can be used as is, or in combination with the rest of the conversion to go full Core XY. I've included a stop that comes with the original pack for completeness.

Warning: I made an error with v1, v2 of the mirrored bracket should properly engage the X ends-top. Check the clearance between the ends-top lever and the screw retaining the pulley bolt. Either move the end-stop down or use a thin nut if necessary. v3 has a recess and should prevent the bolt from impeding the end-stop. Put washers in at the top of the bolt or use a shorter bolt.

I've added a hole for a trim bolt on both v4 brackets. If your print isn't perfectly square, use a m5 trim bolt and nut in each bracket. Check the front of the frame with a right-angle tool, move gantry forward to end-stop position, measure distance to the beam in front of the gantry at each side. Equalise these distances using the trim bolts.

Version history:
V1: Added holes and a groove in the end-stop to access the nut. Left/mirror bracket now deleted.
V2: Fixed the end-stop on the left/mirror bracket.
V3: Added recess for nut near end-stop on the left/mirror bracket.
V4: Added trim screw hole to perfectly square the gantry to both brackets. Widened gantry channel by 0.3mm to allow movement when trimming. Added a long end-stop version. Check hoe your end-stop will fit, if necessary, cut the paddle off on the slicer to give you options, or print mirrored.

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

40% Honeycomb or nearest equivalent

Notes:

As per the original part instructions, print with the following settings :

  • 0.250 mm layer height
  • 5 perimeters with 0.50 mm extrusion width
  • 10 bottom and 10 top layers
  • 40% infill using Simplify3D full honeycomb infill

Imported to Onshape from Fusion 360 as STEP files. Link available here:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/2d61c918ed37344b6f5f4652/w/5cc150713efcf0918f92af5e/e/32e7e772257b2476cbe6bd9c

description.text: This is a small circular knob that fits on a 6mm diameter potentiometer. It is designed to fit snug but shouldn't require too much force to put on.

Ultimaker

Ultimaker 2 Extended

No

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I used a brim to keep the edges from warping. Also, this needs to be printed upside down. i.e. print with the slotted hole facing up.

I designed this using Onshape.com.
Step 1: create your knob profile
Step 2: add the hole with slotj
Step 3: add a helix and curve point plane
Step 4: add a sketch on the new plane with your knurling profile, ie diamond
Step 5: sweep extrude, creating a new part
Step 6: circular pattern around your part
Step 7: mirror your pattern the opposite way to make knurling
Step 8: use a boolean subtract to erase extra parts and get left with one part with knurling now cut into your part
Step 9: print out and enjoy your new knurled knob

I modified the great movable blender model from TiZeta (thank you very much for your awesome work: https://www.blendswap.com/blends/view/66415) to have a helmet and doing the poses I wanted to have. After that I added a baseplate for better stand of the figures.

This was a first test to print minifigures in H0-Scale, because I often read online that it would be impossible to print okay-looking figures for model trains. In my opinion the differences between bought and printed figures is not noticabele at around half a metre distance.
